venue.address_2: 1 Mile West of the Hairpin Turn
venue.name: Greeley Ponds Trailhead

item.description:
Fifty feet of straight up;
The sheer thought of it,
Has me all tingly inside.

Mt Osceola is among the most climbed mountains of the Southern Whites. And why shouldn’t it be? From the southwestern side, the Mt. Osceola Trail barely aspires to be much more than a mildly scary fairy tale, rising 2,000' over the course of a long 3.2 mile one-way climb. But from the north, up East Osceola, the narrative takes on a darker, more menacing tone. From this side, the trail rises nearly 2000' in the span of a mere mile and a half, quickly followed by one of the more storied trail sections in all the Whites: The Chimeny - "fifty feet of straight up."

Where the southwestern approach can be considered more like… let’s say… like those round-bellied, rosy-cheek’d Bavarian tykes Hansel & Gretel, the northern approach is much more like the witch and her sugar-coated, candy-covered gingerbread house. It looks good from the outside (delicious in fact), but once thru the door…

Let’s face it, if it weren’t for the witch, Hansel & Gretal would be a snoozer, a boring story about a boy and a girl walking thru the woods, littering.

I propose we march right into the middle of the house, sit down for a nice meal served to us by a deceitful old woman, pat our bellies when full, and then climb into the oven and do our best not to burn up as we shinny up the flue. (Don't ya like how I worked that in??)


About The Hike
The Trails (out and back): Greeley Ponds Trail (1.3 miles); Mt Osceola Trail (1.5 miles to East Osceola summit + 1.0 mile to Mt Osceola summit).

The hike begins at the Kancamagus Highway, by following the southerly headed Greeley Ponds Trail. Working our way along the moderately graded path toward Greeley Ponds and the Mad River Notch, we'll cross two branches of the South Fork River, before experiencing increasingly rough footing on our way to the Mt Osceola Trail trailhead. Once at the trailhead, we’ll bear right onto the MOT, forgoing the panoramas of the Greeley Ponds Scenic Area, in favor of the scenic overlooks of Mt Osceola. What we will do is use the Scenic Area as a carrot (or in our case, as gingerbread and cupcakes), inspiring us to make “safe” haste, so that we may have a chance to indulge in its deliciousness on our return.

From the Greeley Ponds Trail, the MOT ascends under the watchful eye of East Osceola’s striking crags. On the way up, we’ll clamber over steep sloping rock (that’s “rick” to you JoAnn), cross a rocky slide, and pass thru a gully or two, before summitting East Osceola. Once on the summit, we’ll marvel at all the trees we see, adore the neatly stacked cairn, and applaud the peek-a-boo views we may steal in anticipation of the open, crown-jeweled summit of Mt Osceola.

As we leave East Osceola, we’ll descend moderately, with a steep pitch or two thrown in for good measure. Once descended, we'll begin our rise up the northern slope of Mt Osceola, where we'll eventually come face to face, tête à tête, with The Chimney. It is here that we will have a choice: clamber up, or by using the slightly less precarious "by-pass," saunter around. But no worries… many have succeeded in the past, and so shall you. Once on the summit, we will celebrate, I with my barbaric yawp, and you with your yogic posturing or camera shuttering. After that, we'll eat lunch and head home... hopefully, with enough time on the clock to gratify our appetites with the beauty of Greeley Ponds.

IMPORTANT: There are six RSVP questions to be answered; please answer them or risk losing your place in line.

Note: We'll pay close attention to weather, time and trail conditions, and should there be any adverse weather, such as an approaching thunder storm or heavy rains, or should trail conditions or time prove to be uncooperative, it may be necessary for us to avoid the summits, alter our plans, and/or cancel the hike altogether.


Is This Hike For Me

The Osceola are two of NH 48 4000 footers, capable of offering great views of 41 of the 48 (42 if you look down at your feet), and thou they are often considered moderate hikes, I am calling them advanced, due to the fact that they contain a few strenuous sections and The Chimeny. So, it is very important that you have experience on “like-minded” mountains, such as Monadnock or Cardigan, or a mountain of similar girth or gain. Also, should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact me.

EQUIPMENT CHECKLIST

Cool Weather/Spring Essentials (required):
• Synthetic Quick-drying Wicking Pants/Shorts
• Synthetic Quick-drying Wicking Shirt
• Softshell/Fleece Jacket
• Waterproof/Windproof Shell & Pant
• Synthetic or Wool Sock Liners (wicking layer)
• Synthetic or Wool Socks
• Sturdy Hiking Boots/Shoes (waterproof)
• Hat & Gloves
• Light-weight Insulating Layers (underpant & top)
• Extra pair of Socks
• Lunch
• Snack/Energy Food (extra food)
• Water (min. 2-3L)
• Breadcrumbs
• Map/Compass/Whistle
• Headlamp/Flashlight (w/ fresh lithium batteries)
• Emergency Blanket/Bivy (so small & light, there's no reason not to carry one)

the Remaining Essentials:
• Medication/First Aid Supplies
• Gaiters
• Fire (waterproof matches, lighter, starter)
• Repair Kit/Knife

Optional:
• Sunscreen/Sunglasses/Bug Repellent/Toiletries
• Trekking Poles
• Hand Warmers
• Camera/Binoculars

LET'S NOT UNDERESTIMATE ANYTHING; come prepared for the worst.

Directions

From I-93 take Exit 32 (Lincoln/Kancamagus Hwy Exit). Turn left (east) and follow Route 112E for approx. 9.75 miles.

From the intersection of NH Route 16 & 112, follow 112W for approximately 25.5 miles.

Parking area is located about a mile west of the hairpin-turn-in-the-sky.

Greeley Ponds Trail trailhead: http://maps.google.com/maps...
Coordinates: 44.03142, -71.516892


Additional Information

East Osceola: 4,156 feet
Mt Osceola: 4,340 feet

Distance from trailhead to East Osceola: 2.8 miles
Total distance to Mt Osceola (one-way): 3.8 miles
Total elevation gain (approx.): 2900 feet

Exposure: Moderate/Full
Difficulty: Moderate/Strenuous
Pace: Moderate

Sunrise: 5:07 AM
Sunset: 8:23 PM

Extended AccuWeather Forecast:
http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/lincoln-nh/03251/daily-weather-forecast/2174585

7-Day National Weather Forecast (NOAA):
http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php...

6-Day Mountain-Forecast.com:
http://www.mountain-forecast.com/peaks/Mount-Osceola

Mt. Washington Observatory Higher Summits Forecast:
http://www.mountwashington.org/weather/summit_forecast.php

Weather & Trail Conditions (AMC):
http://www.outdoors.org/recreation/tripplanner/go/backcountry-weather.cfm

Weather & Trail Conditions (TrailsNH):
http://trailsnh.com/New-Hampshire-4000-Footers.php


Liability Waiver

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com; the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
item.how_to_find_us: The Greeley Ponds Trail parking lot is located on the southern side of the Kancamagus Hwy, approx. 9.75 miles from I-93, or 25.5 miles from NH16; Contact Info (cell): 860-460-1500
item.name: East & Mt Osceola by way of Greeley Ponds & the Mad River Notch
